title: For Sale:  Rare Plainfield Ordnance Model 71 - 25acp
postcontent:
Here's a gun you don't come across very often. 

There's not a ton of information about them, but there is a popular rumor that they were designed for the CIA in the late 60s. Here's what a prestigious auction house wrote about one:

QUOTE///
There is a lot of incorrect, conflicting information in regards to the history and production of the Plainfield M1 Carbines and Model 71 Pistols. There is very little published information at all for Plainfield prior to 1970.
Plainfield began business as a small short run tool and die company in New Jersey in the 1950's. The company was approached by the CIA early in 1960. Plainfield was supplied with large quantities of M1 Carbine parts and M1 Garand barrels. Through the 1960's Plainfield manufactured new receivers and modified M1 Garand barrels for use on the M1 Carbines. At their peak, Plainfield had 60 employees assembling large quantities of M1 and M2 Carbines. Employees and others were told the Carbines were for export for the Army. The one sales person handled export from a separate one man office. Calls from individuals to the sales office were never returned.
The FBI showed up at Plainfield to stop the "smuggling" of 1,000 ready to ship M1 Carbines destined for the 1961 Bay of Pigs.

From that point tens of thousands of Carbines were exported to US friendly forces for Vietnam before the war started and to the Orient. The government Carbine work continued through the Kennedy era and only slowed down around 1969-1970. In the late 1960's Plainfield was asked to produce a high quality interchangeable caliber pistol with disposable bolt and barrel. This was quickly accomplished by designer Gary Wilhelm and two highly skilled prototype mechinists. The Plainfield was produced in .22 L.R., .25 A.C.P. and .32 A.C.P. The production of 50-75 in .32 A.C.P. were lost and never accounted for.

All of the work done by Plainfield for the CIA (90%+ of its business) from 1960 - 1970 was done with no publicity or problem.

The decrease of government work at the end of the 1960's may be due to the theft of 46 Carbines during the July, 1967 Plainfield riots (or the theft of 41 Carbines before the riots started!). New Jersey state police and national guardsman started a house to house search for the weapons but were stopped after 1 1/2 hours. Weeks after the riots the FBI and police continued searching with only a few guns recovered.

With the loss of government work Plainfield commercialized the sale of Plainfield Model 71 pistols and Carbines in the early 1970's.

The Plainfield model 71 pistol and conversion offered in this auction is the commercial model which is mechanically identical to the government model.

A unique, well engineered high quality pistol for the semi-automatic collector or shooter.
///END QUOTE

I can't vouch for the accuracy of that story, but either way, the Model 71 is very well made and cleverly engineered. It is SAO and all steel. They also came with a 22lr kit, but this one is only in 25acp. The guns alone are very rare, and extra kits are even more scarce.

Here's an informative review video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dFpmSO2kd8g

I've only put a few magazines through it but it functions fine. Very accurate, too. Sadly, as you can tell, the finish is mostly gone, with maybe 10-20% remaining, and the grips look to have had an "interesting" life. These were originally parkerized, so it may be a fun project to restore the finish to like-new.

The interior parts are in good shape, though, and look almost new.

Also comes with a reproduction manual.

Hoping to get $200 FTF obo in San Antonio, TX, or I could ship for an extra $20.
